54.16: [No.] Perhaps [it deals with a case] when they rented [the courtyard].
54.19: [It is written:] “The Lord will hurl you away violently as a man” (Isaiah 22:17) and Rav said:
54.31: To what does this refer? To a case when she was divorced after marriage, but if she was divorced after betrothal, she may collect the payments herself, because he is not [so] familiar with her.
54.30: It is taught in [Tractate] Evel Rabbati :
54.36: We see that they are familiar with one another.
54.34: Did not R. Nahman say: “It is taught in Evel Rabbathi etc.”?
54.33: R. Adda b. Matanah said to him:
54.55: And it is necessary [to teach all three cases]: For if he had taught us [with regard to] his father, [I might say] that is because he was always with him, but [with regard to] his teacher [he would] not [be believed].
54.32: Once a betrothed and his [former] fiancee came before Rava, and R. Adda b. Matanah, sat before him. Rava placed a messenger between them.
54.57: And if he had taught us these two [cases], [I might say with regard to] his father, that is because he was always with him, and [with regard to] his teacher, because he had reverence for him, but [with regard to] his brother, in regard to whom there is neither this nor that ground, I might say [that he is] not [believed]; so he teaches us [that]
54.50: “That he used to take a share with us at the threshing floor”; “That this place was a bet ha-peras”;

57.24: “And she shall be his wife” (Deuteronomy 22:29). Shimon the Yemenite says:
57.25: A woman who can become his wife;
57.27: A woman who can remain his wife.
57.20: “maiden”, “maiden”, “the maiden”, “virgin”, “virgins”, “the virgins”: Two [are necessary] for themselves, one for the teaching of Abaye, and one for the gezerah shave,
57.21: [and] two remain over: once to include those prohibited by negative commandment and once to include those punishable with karet.
57.22: This [mishnah] excludes [the view of] the following tanna:
57.28: What difference is there between them?
57.40: what is the difference between them?
57.1: But are these entitled to the fine!
57.0: also the fine [applies] when the sale [applies].
57.3: It reads here: “And she shall be his wife” (Deuteronomy 22:29), [that means] one who is fit to be his wife?
57.6: once is necessary for itself, once to include those prohibited by negative commandment and once to include those punishable with karet.
57.9: once is necessary for itself, once to include those prohibited by negative commandment and once to include those punishable with karet.
57.39: Whenever the marriage is forbidden in Israel the child [of such marriage] is a mamzer,
57.38: Come and let us cry out against Akiba b. Joseph, who says:
57.11: That [verse] he requires for [the same teaching] as that of Abaye,
57.10: Why does R. Papa not agree with Resh Lakish?
57.13: If he had relations with her and she died, he is exempt, for it is said: “And he shall give to the father of the young girl” [this means]: To the father of the young girl, but not to the father of a dead [person].
57.15: That [verse] he requires for an analogy (gezerah shavah)
57.14: And why did not Resh Lakish say the same as R. Papa?
57.17: [It is written:] “He shall pay money according to the bride-price (mohar) of virgins,” (Exodus 22:16)  [this means that] this shall be like the mohar of virgins, and the mohar of virgins shall be like this.
57.18: But Resh Lakish also requires it for [the same teaching] as that of Abaye, and R. Papa also requires it for the gezerah shavah (the analogy)?
57.31: According to him who says that she can become his wife, here also there is the possibility of her becoming his wife. And according to him who says that there must be the possibility of her remaining his wife, here there is not the possibility of her remaining his wife.
57.30: The difference between them is with regard to a mamzeret and a netinah.
57.37: And according to R. Yeshebav, who says:
57.36: Of all R. Akiba makes mamzerim, except [the offspring of] a widow and a high priest, for the Torah says: “He shall not take” and “he shall not profane,” (Leviticus 21:14-15) [this teaches that] he makes [his offspring] profane, but not mamzerim.
57.35: for it is taught: R. Simai says:
57.34: There is a difference between them in the case of a widow who marries a high priest, and this according to R. Simai,
57.33: There can be no betrothal when [the woman] is prohibited by a negative commandment, what is the difference between them?
57.32: But according to R. Akiva, who says:

56.13: from [the time that] she grows two pubic hairs until she becomes mature, the [laws of the] fine apply to her, but not [the laws of the] sale, the words of R. Meir;
56.12: A small girl from the age of one day until [the time that] she grows two pubic hairs, [the laws of] sale apply to her, but not the [laws of] fine;
56.15: Wherever sale applies, the fine does not apply, and wherever the fine applies, sale does not apply.
56.17: A small girl from the age of three years and one day until [the time that] she becomes mature — the fine applies to her.
56.18: The fine yes but not the sale!
56.1: If one had intercourse with a mamzeret, a netinah, a Samaritan;
56.0: These are girls to whom the fine is due:
56.3: If one had intercourse with his sister, with the sister of his father, with the sister of his mother, with the sister of his wife, with the wife of his brother, with the wife of the brother of his father, or with a woman during menstruation, he has to pay the fine, [for] although these are punishable through karet, there is not, with regard to them, a death [penalty inflicted] by the court.
56.2: Or with a convert, a captive, or a slave-woman, who was redeemed, converted, or freed [when she was] under the age of three years and one day.
56.4: These prohibited maidens get the fine, [but] fit ones [do] not?
56.7: If anyone had intercourse with a mamzeret, a netinah, a Samaritan, etc.
56.6: These are prohibited maidens who get the fine.
56.9: Who is the Tanna [who taught this]? Rav Judah said in the name of Rav:
56.8: A young girl [receives a fine], [but not] a minor.

51.24: And the Sages said to them:
51.25: If you believe [the witnesses] that she had been taken as collateral, believe [them also] that she was not secluded and that she was not defiled, and if you do not believe [them] that she was not secluded and that she was not defiled, do not believe [them] that she was pledged.
51.26: Now Ashkelon [was a town in which] the hand of the non-Jews was strong over themselves
51.20: GEMARA. R. Shmuel b. Yitzchak said in the name of Rav:
51.21: They have taught [this] only when the hand of Israel is strong over the non-Jews but when the hand of the non-Jews is strong over themselves, even if for the sake of money, she is forbidden to her husband.
51.23: R. Yose the priest and R. Zechariah b. HaKatzav testified regarding an Israelite woman, who had been taken as collateral in Ashkelon and her family distanced her and her witnesses testified that she had not been secluded [with a man] and that she was not defiled [by a man].
51.3: and [then] one witness came and said,
51.2: and said [that] he is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a halutzah and they demoted him [again]
51.5: All agree that the [two witnesses] are joined into one testimony, but they differ as to whether we are afraid of disgracing the court.
51.4: “I know that he is a priest.
51.7: Since we demoted him we do not raise him, [again] because we are afraid of disgracing the court.
51.9: We have demoted him and we can raise him and we are not concerned of bringing disgrace on the court.
51.8: And R. Shimon b. Gamaliel holds:
51.11: If so, even [when there are] two and two also?
51.13: they differ as to whether they are joined into one testimony. And they are arguing about the same issue as the following tannaim,
51.15: Their testimonies are not joined together unless they have both seen [the event] at the same time. Joshua b. Korha says:
51.17: And their testimonies cannot be upheld in court until they both testify at the same time Natan says:
51.16: Even when [they have seen] one after another.
51.19: A woman was imprisoned by non-Jews: If for the sake of money, she is permitted to her husband, And if in order to take her life, she is forbidden to her husband..
51.18: We hear the evidence of one today and when the other one comes tomorrow we hear his evidence.

50.24: One who shares with his brother’s at the court terumah that was part of his father’s property, it is not a presumption.
50.27: Since these [get their share of terumah] in order to eat it, so too this one also [gets his share of terumah] in order to eat it. So he teaches us [that]
50.20: [He could not be regarded as] a Levite, because he was not a Levite. What then could you say? That he was the son of a divorced woman or the son of a halutzah? Even so there is no question, for according to the one who says [that] the first tithe is forbidden to strangers they would not have given [it] to him. And even according to the one who says that the first tithe is permitted to strangers, this refers only to give to them but as part of the distribution, they would not give it to him.
50.21: But he who takes a share through the court, [this] is not a presumption.
50.22: If through the court it is not a presumption, what is presumption?
50.23: Sheshet said: This is what he means:
50.28: those [get the terumah] for eating and this one for selling.
50.40: “I know that he is a priest” and they raised him [again]
50.1: As that which Rav Judah said in the name of Shmuel:
50.3: “I remember when I was a child and riding on my father’s shoulder, they took me out from school and stripped me of my shirt and immersed me  so that I could eat terumah in the evening.”
50.2: It happened that a man was talking innocently and said:
50.5: And my friends kept away from me
50.7: It was taught R. Shimon b. Elazar says:
50.6: and called me ‘Yohanan the hallot-eater.” And Rabbi raised him to the priesthood on his testimony.
50.9: The first tithe belongs to the Levite?!
50.8: Just as terumah is a presumption for the priesthood, so is the first tithe a presumption for the priesthood, but he who takes a share through the court, [this] is not a presumption.
50.39: Rather here we are dealing with a case where we have a presumption that the father of this [person] is a priest and a rumor came out concerning him that he is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a halutzah and they demoted him from the priesthood, and one witness came and said,
50.38: All agree that an objection [must come from] at least two persons?
50.12: Terumah belongs to the priest, the first tithe to the Levite, the words of R. Akiva.
50.15: Say that R. Elazar ben Azariah says: “Also to the priest” does he say: to the priest and not to the Levite?
50.14: The first tithe belongs also to the priest.
50.17: But perhaps it happened that they gave it to him?
50.16: Yes. after Ezra had punished them.
50.19: What are we dealing with here? A case where we know that his father was a priest and a rumor came out concerning him that he was the son of a divorced woman or a halutzah and [yet] they gave him tithe at the threshing floor.
50.31: Shimon b. Gamaliel is the same as R. Eliezer?
50.30: One does not raise [a person] to the priesthood on the testimony of one witness, etc… [ Rabbi Shimon ben Gamaliel says in the name of Rabbi Shimon the son of the assistant chief of priests: [a person] to the priesthood through the testimony of one witness.]
50.36: an objection [must come from at least] two [people],
50.35: [can be accepted from] one [person] and R. Shimon b. Gamaliel holds that
50.34: R. Eliezer holds that an objection
50.33: they differ with regard to an objection raised by one person [in] that

53.56: And in another [baraita] it was taught:
53.54: Shall we say that this difference is like that between [these] tannaim? [For it was taught]:
53.42: I Go and bring witnesses that you are his brother.
53.61: When that baraita was taught, it referred to a woman who talked in her simplicity.
53.62: Like that which R. Dimi said when he came: R. Hanan of Carthage told a story:
53.63: A case came before R. Joshua b. Levi (or as some say R. Joshua b. Levi told a story:
53.64: A case came before Rabbi): Someone was talking in his simplicity and said:
53.49: [Surely] he who wishes to extract money from his fellow, must provide the evidence.
53.66: And Rabbi allowed her to marry a priest by [the words of] his mouth.
53.69: Her hand did not move out of my hand from the time that the non-Jews entered Jerusalem until they departed.”
53.52: But they might still come and lie?
53.53: Two things they will not do.
53.24: In the one case [it speaks of] her handmaid, in the other case [it speaks of] his handmaid.
53.25: But is her handmaid really not believed?
53.27: “No one may testify as to himself?” [Implying] her handmaid is believed!
53.20: even a handmaid except her own handmaid, because she is familiar with her own handmaid!
53.22: In [the case of] a female captive they were lenient.
53.46: Go you and bring witnesses that he is not your brother.
53.44: I have witnesses, but they are afraid of him, because he is a powerful man.
53.45: He [then] said to the other man:
53.40: He answered you well, for it is written: “And Joseph knew his brothers, but they did not know him” (Genesis 22:8) This teaches that he went away before he had grown a beard and he came back after growing a beard.
53.1: But why should this be different from the following case of someone who hired out a donkey to a person, and he said to him,
53.0: why would she lie” or do we not say it?
53.3: But he went the way of Nehar Pekod and the donkey died.
53.2: “Do not go the way of Nehar Pekod. where there is water, go the way of Naresh, where there is no water.”
53.6: ‘Indeed, I went the way of Nehar Pekod, but there was no water.
53.9: If he wished he could have said,
53.78: It has been taught: If someone has divorced his wife, she may not get married [and live] in his neighborhood.
53.51: This is how I rule for you and all who are powerful like you!
53.39: He [then] came to R. Hisda, and he said to him:
53.65: I and my mother were taken captives among the non-Jews. When I went out to draw my water, my mind was on my mother.   [When I was out] to gather wood, my mind was on my mother.
53.76: [Do I say:] There it was allowed because in [the case of] a captive woman they were lenient, but not here. Or is there no difference?
53.75: May one do so with regard to one’s divorcee?
53.73: And nevertheless, he set aside a house for her in his courtyard, and when she would go out, she went out at the head of her children, and when she would come in, she came in at the head of her children.
53.59: But is the view of R. Papa according to the Tannaim?
53.58: Now the views of R. Papi and R. Ashi are [certainly] according to the difference of the Tannaim.
53.12: We do not say “Why should he lie?’ where there are witnesses.
53.15: It is [only] a concern, and in the case of a mere concern we do say [“why should he lie?”].
53.14: There there were witnesses that there certainly was water on the way of Nehar Pekod, but here has she certainly been defiled?
53.17: And even her own handmaid is believed.
53.16: If there are witnesses, even a slave, even a handmaid, they are believed.
53.19: She should not be secluded with him unless there are witnesses, even a slave,
53.18: But we raise a contradiction against this:
53.31: There, where her silence makes her permitted, she is not believed, but here, where her silence makes her forbidden she is believed.
53.30: In both cases [it speaks of] her handmaid. A handmaid sees and is silent.
53.36: Give me a share in the property of our father.
53.34: As in the case of Mari b. Isak [or as some say of Hana b. Isak], a brother came to him from Be-Hozae
53.55: This testimony: a man and a woman, a boy and a girl, her father and her mother, her brother and her sister [may testify], but not her son and her daughter, nor her slave and her handmaid.
53.32: Now also, she may come and lie?
53.57: All are believed to testify [for her] except herself and her husband.

52.56: And Rava said, and some say R. Yohanan:
52.42: With regard to this R. Judah Nesiah and the rabbis argued about this: One said:
52.43: there [it speaks] of a besieging troop of the same kingdom and here of a besieging troop of another kingdom, and he found no difficulties,
52.61: In that case, there is certainly an impurity, [but] here who says that any one has been defiled?
52.63: If she said, “I have not hidden myself and I have not been defiled,” what is [the law]?
52.49: What is [the law] if [the hiding place] holds only one?
52.52: But why is this different from the case of two paths, one clean and one unclean, and someone walked in one of them and [then] prepared clean things and another person came and walked in the second path and [then] prepared clean things. Judah says:
52.53: If each one comes to ask separately, they are [declared] clean; [but] if they both come together, they are [declared] unclean.
52.24: Even if they have not yet been sentenced to death.
52.25: A town that has been conquered by a besieging troop: all the priests’ wives who are in it are prohibited [from their husbands].
52.26: If they have witnesses, even a slave, even a female slave, they are believed.
52.27: A person is not believe about themselves.
52.20: As for instance, the wife of Ben Dunai.
52.22: This is only when they have [already] been sentenced to death.
52.46: Idi b. Abin said in the name of R. Yitzchak b. Ashian:
52.47: If there is there one hiding place, it protects all of the priestly women.
52.44: Whereas one raised all those difficulties and he resolved [them by saying]
52.45: when they placed round the town chains, dogs, sticks, and geese.
52.28: GEMARA. They raised a contradiction against this:
52.29: If a reconnoitring troop comes to a town
52.40: When they placed round the town, chains, wooden sticks and geese.
52.1: [No] the same applies also to [the case if] she had been imprisoned, and the case just happened this way.
52.0: and he teaches when she was taken as collateral” but not “when she was imprisoned”?
52.3: We have also learned this [in a Mishnah]:
52.2: There are those who say: Rav said:
52.5: And the Sages said to them:
52.4: R. Yose the priest and R. Zechariah b. HaKatzav testified regarding an Israelite woman, who had been taken as collateral in Ashkelon and her family distanced her and her witnesses testified that she had not been secluded [with a man] and that she was not defiled [by a man].
52.7: Now Ashkelon where [it happened] for the sake of money, and [yet] the reason [why she was permitted her to her husband was] because witnesses testified concerning her, but if witnesses did not testify concerning her [she would] not [have been permitted]; and is it not [also to be supposed] that there is no difference whether she was pledged or imprisoned?
52.6: If you believe [the witnesses] that she had been taken as collateral, believe [them also] that she was not secluded and that she was not defiled, and if you do not believe [them] that she was not secluded and that she was not defiled, do not believe [them] that she was pledged.
52.9: Some put in the form of a contradiction. We have learned:
52.8: No, when she was pledged it is different.
52.51: of each one was the one [who hid there] or do we not say this?
52.38: [But still] it is not possible that one does not sleep a little!
52.59: Now here also, since all [ the women] were permitted, it is like [the case where they came] at the same time?
52.58: they differ only when one comes to ask for himself and for the other one; one treats this as [if it were] at the same time, and the other regards this as [if it were] one after another.
52.10: if for the sake of money she is permitted to her husband.
52.12: R. Yose testified etc. [Now] in Ashkelon [it happened] for the sake of money and [yet] the reason [why she is permitted to her husband] is because witnesses testify concerning her, but if no witnesses testify concerning her, [she would] not [have been permitted].
52.15: It is no contradiction; here  [it speaks] when the hand of Israel is strong over the non-Jews, [and] there when the hand of the non-Jews is strong over themselves.
52.16: If for the purpose of [taking her] life she is forbidden [to her husband].
52.18: As for instance the wives of thieves.
52.31: In times of war both are permitted, because they have no time to offer libations.
52.30: in time of peace the open casks [of wine] are forbidden and the closed ones are permitted.
52.36: Rav Judah said in the name of Shmuel:
52.35: Here [it speaks] of a besieging troop of the same kingdom here [it speaks] of a besieging troop of another kingdom. [Even in the case of a besieging troop] of the same kingdom, it is not possible that at least one of them did not run away [from the rest of the troop]!
52.34: Yitzchak b. Elazar said in the name of Hezekiah:
52.33: To have intercourse they have time, to offer libations they have no time.
52.55: In both cases they are [declared] unclean.
52.57: [If they come to ask] at the same time, all agree that they are [declared] unclean, if they come one after another, all agree that they are [declared] clean;

115.54: Rav and Shmuel hold that [the rabbis]
115.48: The surplus is consecrated while she is still alive.
115.52: But if it is a case where [the husband] does not provide her maintenance and does not provide her a silver ma’ah for her other needs, what is the reason of the one who stated that “it becomes consecrated while she is still alive?”
115.53: This is a case indeed where he does provide her maintenance; but does not provide her a silver ma’ah for her other needs.
115.24: Even according to the one who holds that a master has the right to say to his slave, “Work for me but I will not maintain you,” such a rule applies only to a Canaanite slave concerning whom Scripture has not written “with you,”
115.25: but not to a Hebrew slave concerning whom it is written in Scripture, “With you,” all the more so he could not say so to his wife.
115.26: It  was necessary [as an introduction to] the final clause:
115.27: [Concerning the] surplus: Rabbi Meir says: it is consecrated.
115.20: One who consecrated his wife’s handiwork she may nevertheless continue to work and to consume [the proceeds herself].
115.21: Does not [this refer to a wife who can be maintained by her husband?
115.22: No; [it is a case where the husband is unable to] provide her maintenance.
115.23: If this is a case where [her husband is unable to] provide her maintenance, what does this teach us?
115.46: The surplus becomes consecrated only after [the wife’s] death.
115.41: From that you can learn [that R. Meir holds that one can consecrate something not yet in existence] but from this [mishnah] you cannot learn.
115.1: What then is [the reason for] the difference?
115.0: But according to R. Shmuel b. Judah the earlier [ruling of the] Mishnah is due to a bodily defect and the latter is also due to a bodily defect!
115.2: The difference is the [efficacy of an] examination by outsiders.
115.5: an examination by others is not regarded as effective.
115.4: is of the opinion that an examination by others is regarded as effective, while the other Master holds the opinion that
115.6: If a man consecrated his wife’s handiwork, she continues to work and to consume [that which she makes].
115.8: it is consecrated. Rabbi Yohanan Hasandlar says:
115.51: If we say: Where [the husband] provides her maintenance and also provides her a silver ma’ah for her other needs, what is the reason of the one who stated that it “becomes consecrated only after death”?
115.39: If a man said to a woman, “Behold you are betrothed to me after I convert,” or “After you convert,” or “After I have been set free,” or “After you have been set free,” or “After your husband dies,” “After your sister died,” or “After your brother-in-law performs halitzah for you:” R. Meir says:
115.11: A woman may say to her husband, “I do not wish either to be maintained by you or to work for you.”
115.10: GEMARA. R. Huna said in the name of Rav:
115.13: when the rabbis enacted [the relations of husband and wife] her maintenance was fundamental while [he receives] her handiwork in order [to prevent] enmity.
115.14: Therefore, if she said, “I do not wish either to be maintained by you or to work for you,” she is entitled to do so.
115.16: They enacted that she receives maintenance in return for her handiwork.
115.19: Shall we say that [our Mishnah] provides support for his view?
115.18: They enacted that he receives her handiwork in return for sustaining her.
115.30: This [R. Huna’s ruling] disagrees with that of Resh Lakish.
115.37: But does R. Meir hold that a man cannot consecrate anything that is not yet in existence?
115.36: a man does not utter his words to no purpose, it is as if he had actually said to her, “May your hands be consecrated to He who created them.”
115.35: Since we heard R. Meir say:
115.34: But, surely, he did not say this!
115.33: Since [a husband] has the right to compel her to work, it is as if he said to her “May your hands be consecrated to He who created them.”
115.32: You should not say that R. Meir’s reason is because he is of the opinion that a man may consecrate that which has not yet come into existence. Rather, this is R. Meir’s reason:

114.24: A yavam [who is a priest] does not confer [upon his sister-in-law] the right of eating terumah.
114.26: The Torah says, “The purchase of his money,” (Leviticus 22:11) and this one is the purchase of his brother.
114.27: If she had spent six months with her husband.
114.21: Wherever terumah was mentioned [the woman] is to be given double the amount in unconsecrated food.
114.22: What is the practical difference between them?
114.23: The difference between them is who must bother [to sell the terumah].
114.28: Now that you stated [that even if she spent the full twelve months less one day] with the husband [she is] not [permitted to eat terumah] is there any need [to mention] before the yavam?
114.29: It was taught as a “this, and there is not even any need to say this.”
114.1: An armed robber or assigned to death by the government—these are well-known.
114.0: a gambler, the acquisition is still valid.
114.3: The difference between them [is the case where her intended husband]
114.2: Whether according to the [explanation of the one] Master or according to that of the other Master she is not permitted to eat [terumah], what then is the practical difference between them?
114.4: accepted [her defects, or where her father] delivered [her to the intended husband’s agents] or went [with them].
114.6: All [the sustenance] for such a woman may be given in terumah etc.
114.8: The dispute applies only to the daughter of a priest who was betrothed to a priest but with respect to the daughter of an Israelite who was betrothed to a priest all agree [that he gives her] one half unconsecrated food and one half terumah.
114.11: So it was also taught: R. Tarfon said,
114.10: Their dispute relates to one who was only betrothed, but in respect of a married woman all agree [that she is supplied with] one half unconsecrated food and one half terumah.
114.13: One half consecrated food and one half terumah.
114.12: All [the sustenance] for such a woman is given of terumah. R. Akiva said,
114.15: To what does this apply? To one who was only betrothed but in respect of a married woman all agree [that she is supplied with] one half unconsecrated food and one half of terumah.

107.28: Any man who gives a virgin less than two hundred zuz or a widow less than a maneh is engaging in licentious sex.

104.54: In the case of a betrothed wife [the husband] is not subject to the laws of onan, nor may he defile himself for her; and she likewise is not subject to the laws of onan, nor may she defile herself for him. If she dies, he does not inherit from her. If he dies, she collects her ketubah.
104.42: This refers to the ketubah of the male children.
104.60: If a betrothed woman died, she does not receive her kethubah.

104.52: Go and bury her or pay her the ketubah.
104.53: Hiyya said to them, We have taught:

104.27: Why do you not ask the same question in the case of a woman who forgave her claim [to her ketubah]?
104.21: Now, let me change my mind.

104.9: does it also imply that one should be compelled so to act?’
104.8: This applies only [to one who acts] willingly;

105.42: Rather it may be concluded that the difference between them is the case of a minor who had exercised her right of refusal: the first Tanna holds that
105.48: Her ketubah is a charge on the estate of her first husband, she does not have such rights, or is it possible that since the rabbis have enacted that whenever she is unable to collect her ketubah from [the estate of] her first [husband], she may recover it from that of the second, she does have [rights to maintenance]?
105.43: she is entitled [to maintenance]  while R. Judah holds that

39.48: When you think about it, according to Rabbi [Judah Hanasi]

39.15: and if they are old, they are unclean.

38.25: And only when it is produced by another person, but not [if it is produced] by himself.

38.5: set the two [witnesses] against the two [witnesses] and leave the property in the possession of its master.

38.9: he sold [the property] when he was insane, and two came and said that

38.10: he sold [the property] when he was sane.
38.13: And we say this only when he has the presumption of ownership from his ancestors, but if he does not have the presumption of ownership of his ancestors, we say that
38.12: Set the two [witnesses] against the two [witnesses] and leave the property in the possession of the lunatic.
38.14: he bought [the property] when he was insane and that he sold [it] when he was insane.
38.17: And a rebuttal in their absence — granted that it does not count as rebuttal, but it does count as contradiction.
38.16: They rebut witnesses only in their presence, but they contradict them also in not in their presence.
38.19: If there are witnesses that this is their handwriting, or their handwriting came out from another place, [namely] from a document which was contested and was confirmed in court, they are not believed.”
38.31: Only when he remembers it by himself.Only when he remembers it by himself.
38.36: These two people who know evidence and one of them has forgotten it, the other one may remind him of it.
38.35: Learn from [the words of] R. Yohanan [the following]:
38.33: Even if he does not remember it by himself.

33.38: “He teaches us, even if he had become of age.”
33.10: The dripping of oil on the heads of the scholars.

33.15: As that [case when] one of the scholars was occupied with the wedding of his son in the house of Rabbah b. Ulla,
33.14: You orphan, did your mother not do the dripping of the oil on the heads of the scholars at the time of the event?
33.17: What [sign is there at the wedding of] a widow?
33.16: and some say, Rabbah b. Ulla was occupied with the wedding of his son in the house of one of the scholars, and he dripped oil on the heads of the scholars at the time of the event.
33.19: A widow has no roasted ears of grain [distributed at her wedding].

33.30: why should he not be believed?   And if he did not eat [the produce of] it [during the] years of hazakah, it is obvious that he is not believed!
33.37: And if you wish, you may say,
33.36: R. Huna says what is to be derived from our Mishnah by implication.
33.35: If you wish you may say,

33.33: One does not acquire the ownership of the property of a minor through hazakah even if [he continued in the possession after] the minor had become of age.

31.6: But let us be concerned that she might produce witnesses before this court and collect her ketubah and then later produce the ketubah before another court and collect [a second time] by that [document]!
31.38: “This one is worthy of eating terumah.”

31.13: If she lost her ketubah document, or she hid it, or it was burned: If they danced before her, played before her, passed before her the cup of [glad] tidings, or the cloth of virginity, if she has witnesses with regard to one of these, her ketubah is two hundred [zuz].
31.12: Some teach this with regard to the following baraita:
31.14: But let us be concerned that perhaps she might produce witnesses before this court and collect her ketubah and then later produce the ketubah before another court and collect [a second time] by that [document]!
31.19: We are dealing with a place where they do not write a ketubah.

31.30: If she lost it, it is as if she had hidden it before us, and we do not give her [the ketubah money] until witnesses say [that] her ketubah document has been burned.
31.37: They pass before her a cup of wine of terumah, as if to say,
31.36: Rav Adda the son of Ahava said:

31.34: “[If] they passed before her the cup of glad tidings.”
31.33: In a case where it is not possible otherwise, we certainly write a receipt.

35.25: They are not believed to disqualify it, the words of R. Meir.

35.28: This goes well according to the rabbis, who follow their reasoning, “the mouth that prohibits is the mouth that permits,”
35.29: but what is the reason of R. Meir?
35.1: “as soon as I will have money I will pay it,”
35.0: He would like to admit that he owes the whole debt, and the reason he does not admit, is that he would like to elude him [for the time being]. And he thinks,
35.3: Impose an oath on him, so that he should admit the whole of it.
35.5: he is not brazen against him nor against his son, and therefore he is not like one who returns a lost thing.
35.7: against him he is not brazen, but against his son he might be brazen, and since he is not brazen, he is like one who returns a lost thing.
35.9: “This is our handwriting, but we were forced, [or] we were minors, [or] we were disqualified witnesses” they are believed.

34.24: If so, [it is not] “his own statement?”

34.8: R. Joshua admits that if one says to his fellow,

60.24: If someone was removing objects from one corner to another corner and changed his mind and carried them out he is exempt because the taking up was not from the outset for that [purpose]?
60.25: Do not say [he picked it up] in order to hide it, rather say [he picked it up] in order to carry it out. Here we are dealing with a case where he [paused and] remained standing [for a while].
60.26: For what purpose did he stand?
60.27: If to adjust [the weight], this is the usual way.
60.20: Here also we should say: The lifting up is necessary for the carrying out!
60.21: Here also we should say: The lifting up is necessary for the carrying out!
60.22: [But] is he, in such a case guilty [of trangressing Shabbat]?
60.23: Did not R. Simon say [that] R. Ammi said in the name of R. Yohanan:
60.28: Rather where he stood still in order to rest. But if he stood in order to adjust the weight what is the rule?
60.0: and [at the same time] tore the silk garments of his neighbor.
60.3: Shall we say he disagrees with R. Abin? For R. Abin said:
60.2: R. Nehunia b. Hakaneh agrees that, if someone stole [forbidden] fat belonging to his neighbor and ate it, he is liable [to pay], because he was guilty of stealing before he came to the prohibition with of [forbidden] fat.
60.5: Here too the lifting up was necessary for the eating.
60.4: If someone threw an arrow [on Shabbat] from the beginning of four [cubits] to the end of four [cubits] and it tore silk garments in its passage he is exempt [from payment], for the uprooting was necessary for the putting down.
60.7: There the “putting down” is impossible without the “uprooting”; but here the eating is possible without the “lifting up,” for if he wants, he could bend down and eat.
60.9: there if he wants to take it back, he cannot take it back; but here, he can put it back.
60.11: The difference between them is [in the following case]: One who carries a knife in the public domain and it tore silk garments in its passage:
60.10: What is the [practical] difference between the one answer and the other answer?
60.13: here also the “putting down” is impossible without the “uprooting.”  And according to the answer that he cannot take it back, here he can take it back.
60.12: According to the answer that the “putting down” is impossible without the “uprooting”
60.15: If someone threw [on Sabbath] an arrow from the beginning of four [cubits] to the end of four [cubits] and it tore silk garments in its passage he is exempt [from payment], for the “uprooting” was necessary for the “putting down.”
60.14: The text [stated above]: R. Abin said:
60.17: If someone stole a purse on Shabbat he is obligated [to pay], because he was guilty of stealing before he came to the [transgression of] the prohibition punishable with stoning,
60.16: Bibi b. Abaye raised an objection:
60.18: but if he dragged it along he is exempt [from payment], because the desecration of Shabbat and the stealing come at the same time.

61.42: He who has intercourse with his sister, with the sister of his father, with the sister of his mother, with the sister of his wife, with the sister of his brother, with the wife of the brother of his father, or with a woman during menstruation,
61.24: Indeed, when he carried it out into the public road, for he acquires also in the public ground.
61.25: [And] they differ with regard to a deduction from this Mishnah, for we have learned:
61.26: If he was pulling it out and it died in the domain of the owner, he is exempt. But if he lifted it up or brought it out from the domain of the owner and it died, he is obligated [to pay].
61.27: Ravina makes a deduction from the first clause, and R. Aha makes a deduction from the second clause.
61.21: The hand of a person is regarded as [a place of] four by four [handbreadths].
61.28: Ravina makes a deduction from the first clause:
61.29: “If he was pulling it out and it died in the domain of the owner, he is exempt.”
61.40: They raised a contradiction against this:

61.1: “When was this said?  If he stood still to rest; but if [he stood still] to adjust the weight, he is exempt [from payment]”?
61.0: He would be exempt. [If so] instead of teaching “but if he dragged it along he is exempt [from payment],” let it teach the distinction in the same case:
61.3: one who walks is like one who stands.
61.2: Rather, whose opinion is this? It is Ben Azzai who said that
61.5: When was this said? When he walked, but when he threw it, he is exempt.
61.4: [But] what would be the rule if he threw [the purse]?  He would be exempt [from payment]. Let him then make the distinction in the same case:
61.7: this is not the way of carrying out, so he teaches us [that it is a way of carrying out].
61.6: The case of dragging it along need [to be stated]. Lest you would have said that
61.9: If large, this is the ordinary way [of carrying it out], and if small, this is not the ordinary way?
61.39: One who has sex with his sister, or with the sister of his father, etc.
61.38: for we do not say [that] bringing out is like lifting up.
61.11: If he carried it into the public domain, there is a transgression of Shabbat but no stealing, and if he carried it into the private domain, there is stealing but no transgression of Shabbat!
61.10: Rather it was medium sized. But where did he carry it to?
61.12: No, it is necessary [to state it] when he carried it out to the sides of the public road.
61.15: The sides of the public road are like the public road, there is a transgression of Shabbat but no stealing and
61.14: If according to R. Eliezer, who says:
61.17: Indeed, it is according to R. Eliezer, and when R. Eliezer says: The sides of the public road are like the public road, these words refer only to the obligation for transgressing Shabbat, because sometimes people push and go there, but with regard to acquiring, one does acquire there. Why [not]? Because the public is not often there.
61.16: if it is according to the rabbis, who say: The sides of the public road are not like the public road, there is stealing but no transgression of Shabbat?
61.19: It refers to a case where he lowered his hand to less than three [handbreadths] and received it. [And this is] according to Rava,
61.31: Aha makes a deduction from the second clause:
61.30: The reason [he is exempt] is because it died in the domain of the owner, but if he had brought it out from the domain of the owner and it died, he would have been obligated [to pay].
61.37: The second clause is not difficult to Ravina,
61.36: for as long as it has not come into his possession it is called “in the domain of the owner.”
61.35: The first clause is not difficult to R. Aha,
61.34: According to R. Aha the first clause is difficult and according to Rabina the second clause is difficult?
61.33: so too bringing out [must he an act through which the object] comes into his possession.
61.32: “But if he lifted it up or brought it out [etc.]” Bringing out is like lifting up; just as lifting up is [an act through which the object] comes into his possession,

62.11: From where does Ulla derive this?
62.10: Wherever there is a monetary payment and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes.
62.13: Just as when one person injures another person, where there is a monetary payment and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes,
62.12: He derives it from [the law with regard to] one person who injures another person.
62.15: Rather he derives it from the case of plotting witnesses.
62.14: so too whenever there is a payment of money and a punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. But it is different with [the case of] one who injures another because he is liable for five things?And [if you will say] that [the payment of] money is still lighter, [one can say against this] that [here it has been excepted] from its rule [and] permitted to the court!
62.17: [But it may be argued] it is different with the case of plotting witnesses, because they do not require a warning? [And if you will say] that [the payment of] money is lighter, [one can say against this,] that they have not done any deed!
62.16: Just as in the case of plotting witnesses, whose transgression involves the payment of money and the punishment with lashes, they pay the money but do not receive the lashes, so too whenever there is payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes.
62.19: The point common to both is that there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, and in either case he pays the money and does not receive the lashes. So whenever there is payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays the money and does not receive the lashes.
62.18: Rather he derives it from both (plotting witnesses and personal injury).
62.20: But [it may be argued] the point common to both is [also] that they both have a strict side? And if [you will say that the payment of] money is lighter, [one can say against this] that they have both a lighter side?
62.0: and we hold that one does not receive lashes and pay!
62.3: Here [it speaks] of his sister [who is] a young girl, and there [it speaks] of his sister [who is] a mature girl.
62.5: It refers to one not of sound senses.
62.4: [But in the case of] his sister [who is] a mature girl, too, [there are damages to be paid for the] shame and damage?
62.7: [It speaks of] a girl who was seduced.
62.6: But [there are still damages to be paid for] the pain?
62.8: Now that you have come to this, you can even say [that it speaks of] his sister [who was] a young girl [and namely when she was] an orphan and [she was] seduced.

63.25: The Torah has expressly stated that plotting witnesses have to pay money.
63.26: Where has the Torah stated this?
63.27: Since; it is written: “Then you shall do to him as he had thought to do to his fellow”
63.20: “We testify that So-and-so owes his fellow two hundred zuz” and they were found to be plotting witnesses, they receive the lashes and pay, for the verse that imposes upon them the lashes does not impose upon them the payment, the words of R. Meir; and the Sages say:
63.21: All who pay do not receive lashes.
63.23: He who receives lashes does not pay?
63.28: (Deuteronomy 19:19); why [is it written further,] “hand for hand” (19:21)? Something that is given from hand to hand. And what is this? Money.
63.29: [And] the same applies to the case of one who injures another. Since it is written: “As he has done, so shall it be done to him” (Leviticus 24:19); Why [is it also stated] “So shall it be given to him” (Leviticus 24:20)?  A thing that can be given from hand to hand, and that is money.
63.0: Rather, Ulla derives it from the two words “tahat:”  It is written here “Since (tahat) he has laid with her” (Deuteronomy 22:29) and it is written there: “Eye for (tahat) eye.” Just as there he pays money and does not receive lashes, so wherever there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays money and does not receive the lashes.
63.3: Here it speaks of a case where they warned him, and here it speaks of a case where they did not warn him.
63.2: You can even say that it speaks of his sister who was a young girl [and you can resolve the contradiction in the following way]:
63.5: wherever there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes and they warned him, he receives the lashes and does not pay the money.
63.6: From where does R. Yohanan derive this?
63.9: But behold when one person injures another person, in which case there is the payment of money and the punishment of lashes, he pays money and does not receive the lashes?
63.8: “According to his guilt” (Deuteronomy 25:2); you punish him because of one guilt but not because of two guilts, and immediately following [it says]: “He shall strike him with forty lashes.”
63.11: this is only when they did not warn him, but when they warned him, he receives the lashes and does not pay — did not R. Ammi say in the name of R. Yohanan that,
63.10: And if you will say that
63.12: if one person struck another person a blow, for which no perutah can be claimed as damages, he receives the lashes?
63.14: If they did not warn him, why would he receive the lashes?
63.16: they warned him, and the reason [why he receives the lashes and does not pay] is because the damages do not amount to a perutah, but if they amount to a perutah he pays the money but does not receive the lashes!
63.19: Where was the teaching of R. Ila said? On the following:
63.18: The Torah has expressly stated that plotting witnesses have to pay money; so [here] also the Torah has expressly stated that the person who injures another person has to pay money.
63.31: If so you would abolish [the lashes accorded to one who transgresses]: “The nakedness of your sister you shall not uncover” (Leviticus 18:9).
63.30: Why does R. Yohanan not say as Ulla?

64.25: For if you thought that plotting witnesses require a warning, if we have not warned them, we would not kill them. [But then] is it possible that who they wished to kill without a warning, that they should require a warning?
64.26: Surely, we need to fulfill “then you shall do to him as he has plotted to do to his brother,” and this could not be fulfilled.
64.27: Samma the son of R. Jeremiah raised a difficulty:
64.20: Let us warn them immediately after they have given their evidence?
64.21: Aha the son of R. Ika raised a difficulty:
64.22: Let us warn them at first and hint to them [afterwards].
64.23: Abaye changed his mind and said:
64.28: But now [according to your logic], [if the witnesses testified falsely about someone that he was] the son of a divorced woman or the son of a halutzah since this case is not included in “as he had thought etc.” he should require a warning should be required!
64.1: [And the same could be said of] plotting witnesses: If so you would abolish [the lashes accorded to one who transgresses]: “Then it shall be, if the guilty man deserve to be beaten” (Deuteronomy 25:2).
64.0: [The same could be said] about one who injures another: If so you would abolish [the lashes accorded to one who transgresses], “He shall not exceed, lest, if he should exceed” (Deuteronomy 25:3).
64.3: [Similarly in the case of] one who injured another, it could be fulfilled when he struck him a blow for which no perutah can be claimed as damages.
64.2: Rather [lashing for] plotting witnesses could be fulfilled when [the witnesses testified falsely about someone that he was] the son of a divorced woman or the son of a halutzah.
64.4: [But you could] also say [with regard to] his sister— it could be fulfilled in the case of his sister who was a mature girl!
64.7: The verse says, “Since he had relations with her.” This [he shall pay] for he has had relations with her, [from which we infer] by implication, that there is also payment for shame and damages.
64.6: [The verse] “Since (tahat) he had relations with her” is required for the teaching of Abaye, for Abaye said:
64.8: And Ulla? He derives it from a teaching of Rava,
64.39: And even if we say that it is so, how [do we know] that death is more severe?
64.38: From where [do we know] that when one is warned regarding a severe matter one also stands warned for a light matter? Perhaps it is not so!
64.11: “Then the man that lay with her must give to the father of the girl fifty shekel of silver” (Deuteronomy 22:29); for the enjoyment of lying [with her he pays] fifty [shekel of silver], [and from here we infer], by implication, that there is also payment for shame and damages.
64.13: Plotting witnesses pay money and do not receive lashes, because they cannot be warned.
64.15: Know it [from the following logic]: When could we warn them?
64.17: Could we warn them during the deed? They would [then] leave and not testify.
64.16: Could we warn them at first? They will say: We have forgotten.
64.19: Abaye raised a difficulty on this:
64.18: Could we warn them at the end? What has been has been.
64.31: Shisha, the son of R. Idi, said:
64.30: “You shall have one manner of law” (Leviticus 24:22) [this means] a law that is equal for all of you.
64.36: If they did not warn him, why should he be killed? Hence it is obvious that he was warned, [and it is held], when one is warned regarding a severe matter one also is warned for a light matter, and [yet] the Torah says: “And if no harm follow, he shall be surely fined.”
64.34: The verse speaks of fighting with intent to kill, for it is written, “But if any harm follow, then you shall take a life for a life.”
64.33: [It is written:] “And if men fight and harm a woman with child, so that she miscarries,” (Exodus 21:22): [Upon this] R. Elazar said:
64.32: That a person who injures another person pays money and does not receive the lashes is derived from the following:

65.42: Is it anywhere to be found that if he does [the deed] himself he is not liable and if an agent does it he is liable?
65.43: He himself [does not pay], not because he is not liable, but because he receives the more severe penalty
65.25: Whose opinion is this? R. Meir, who says: .
65.26: He receives the lashes and pays [the money]
65.27: If it is according to R. Meir, [then one who violated] his daughter should also [pay the fine]?
65.20: Do you not make a distinction between a beating that has a limit and a beating that has no limit!
65.22: From where [do you know] that he struck him intentionally, and he is cleansed from execution. Perhaps he struck him unintentionally, and he is cleansed from exile.
65.44: But if it had been slaughtered by another person, what is the reason of the rabbis who declare him free [from paying]?
65.28: And if you will say that R. Meir holds [that] one may receive the lashes and pay [the money], but he does not hold [that] one may receive the death penalty and pay [the money], is this so?
65.40: [The word] “instead” comes to include the agent
65.41: Mar Zutra raises a difficulty on this:
65.3: Samma the son of R. Assi said to R. Ashi; and some say [that] R. Samma the son of R. Ashi [said] to R. Ashi:
65.2: If they had lashed Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, they would have worshipped the [golden] image?
65.5: Jacob from Nehar Pekod raised a difficulty:
65.4: Do you not make a distinction between a beating that has a limit and a beating that has no limit!
65.7: Rather R. Jacob from Nehar Pekod said in the name of Rava:
65.6: hat works for the Rabbis who hold that life actually means [life]. But according to Rabbi, who holds that it means money, what is there to say?
65.9: Would you think that this one walks about in the market and that one should be killed?
65.8: [It is to derived] from the following verse: [It is written,] “Should he get up and walk about on his staff then he that smote him shall be cleansed” (Exodus 21:19).
65.38: [The word] “or” comes to include the agent.
65.10: Rather it teaches that they imprison him; if he dies, they kill him; and if he does not die, “he shall pay for the loss of his time, and heal him.”
65.13: Rather it is clear that they warned him, and [it is held], one who was warned for a severe matter stands warned for the lighter matter and the Torah says [that if he does not die] “he shall pay for the loss of his time, and heal him.”
65.12: If they did not warn him, why should he be killed?
65.15: From where [do we know] that when one is warned regarding a severe matter one also stands warned for a light matter?
65.17: Perhaps lashes are more severe, for Rav said: ?
65.16: Perhaps it is not so! And even if we say that it is so, how [do we know] that death is more severe?
65.19: Samma the son of R. Assi said to R. Ashi; and some say [that] R. Samma the son of R. Ashi [said] to R. Ashi:
65.18: If they had lashed Hananiah, Mishael and Azariah, they would have worshipped the [golden] image?
65.31: Has it not been stated regarding this: R. Jacob said in the name of R. Yohanan, and some say [that] R. Jeremiah said in the name of R. Shimon b. Lakish:
65.30: If he has stolen and slaughtered [an animal] on Shabbat, or has stolen and slaughtered [an animal] for idolatry, or has stolen an ox that is to be stoned and slaughtered it, he shall pay fourfold or fivefold, the words of R. Meir, but the sages exempt him [from payment].
65.37: The School of R. Ishmael taught:
65.36: The Torah says: “And he slaughters it or sells it” (Exodus 21:37); just as the sale is performed by another person, so too the slaughter is performed by another person.
65.34: But is it possible that one sins and another one is punished?
65.33: It refers to a case where he [who stole the animal] let it be slaughtered by another person.
65.32: R. Abin and R. Elai and the whole company [of scholars] said in the name of R. Yohanan:

66.24: “It is holy,” “it” is holy, but what has been prepared on it is not holy
66.25: According to the one who says [that the prohibition is only] by the rabbis, what is the reason of the rabbis who declare him exempt?
66.26: The rabbis declare him exempt only with regard to other cases.
66.27: But [with regard to] one who slaughtered for idolatry [one can ask:] as soon as he has cut a little it has become forbidden, so when he continues the slaughtering he is not slaughtering what belongs to the owner?
66.20: What has been prepared on Shabbat [is forbidden] by the Torah, and one says: by the rabbis.
66.22: The one who says: By the Torah, as we have said [above].
66.23: [And] the one who says: By the rabbis — the verse says: .
66.29: [It refers to a case] when he says [that] he worships it with the completion of the slaughtering.
66.1: This is correct with regard to [slaughtering for] idolatry and [slaughtering of] the ox that is to be stoned, but slaughtering on Shabbat is a valid slaughtering, for we have learned:
66.0: Who are the Sages? R. Shimon, who says: An unfit slaughtering is not called slaughtering.
66.3: He holds the opinion of R. Yohanan the Sandler, for it has been taught:
66.2: One who slaughters [an animal] on Shabbat or on Yom Kippur, although he is liable for the death penalty his slaughtering is valid?
66.4: One who cooks on Shabbat, [if] by mistake, he may eat it; if intentionally he may not eat it, the words of R. Meir.
66.6: [If] by mistake, he may eat it Shabbat is over; if intentionally, he may never eat it.
66.9: if intentionally neither he nor others may eat it.
66.8: [If] by mistake, others may eat it after Shabbat but he may not;
66.39: Indeed [it speaks of a case] when he slaughtered it himself an
66.11: As R. Hiyya expounded at the entrance of the house of the Patriarch:
66.10: What is R. Yohanan the Sandler’s reasoning?
66.13: Just as what is holy is forbidden to be eaten, so too what has been prepared on Shabbat is forbidden to be eaten.
66.12: “You shall keep the Shabbat for it is holy to you” (Exodus 31:14).
66.15: It says, “to you,” from this we learn: It shall belong to you.
66.14: If [so, you might say that] just as what is holy is forbidden to be enjoyed, so too what has been prepared on Shabbat should be forbidden to be enjoyed?
66.17: [therefore] it is said: “Those who desecrate it shall surely die” (Exodus 31:14).  I have told you this only when it was done intentionally, not when it was done by mistake.
66.16: You might think [that it is forbidden to eat] even [what has been prepared on Shabbat] by mistake,
66.18: Aha and Rabina argue about this.
66.30: [But with regard to] the ox that is to he stoned, it is not his that he is slaughtering?
66.37: that which causes [the gain or loss of] money is regarded as money.
66.36: And he holds like R. Shimon who says:
66.35: If the guardian returned it even after the sentence had been completed, it is regarded as returned.
66.34: He holds like R. Yaakov who says:
66.33: And R. Meir holds like R. Yaakov and holds like R. Shimon.
66.32: What are we dealing with here? When he handed it to a guardian and it caused the damage in the house of the guardian and it was sentenced in the house of the guardian and a thief stole it from the house of the guardian.

67.24: He who teaches it in reference to the first case, so much the more [does he teach it in reference] to the second case, and he disagrees with R. Papa.
67.25: And he who teaches it in reference to the second case does not teach it in reference to the first case, and he agrees with R. Papa.
67.26: It is alright [that] R. Yohanan does not say like Resh Lakish, because he wants to explain it   according to the rabbis. But why does not Resh Lakish say like R. Yohanan?
67.20: If their father left them a borrowed cow, they may use it during the whole period for which he borrowed it; if it died, they are not responsible.
67.21: If they thought that it belonged to their father and they slaughtered it and ate it, they pay the value of the meat at the lowest price.
67.22: If their father left them an obligation of property, they are liable to pay.
67.23: Some teach it in reference to the first case and some teach it in reference to the second case.
67.28: since he is exempt if they warned him, he is also free [even] if they did not warn him.
67.29: And they follow their own reasoning,
67.1: are different, because the Torah has enacted something novel with regard to a fine, and [therefore]  he has to pay, although he has to suffer the death penalty.
67.0: and R. Meir holds the view that [though generally] one may receive the lashes and pay, one cannot receive the death penalty and pay but these [cases]
67.3: If he had a kid which he had stolen and he slaughtered it on Shabbat, he is obligated, for he was already guilty of stealing before he came to the prohibition of Shabbat;
67.2: And Rabbah follows his own principle, for Rabbah said:
67.4: [but] if he stole and slaughtered it on Sabbath he is free, for if there is no stealing there is no slaughtering and no selling.
67.7: [But] if he stole and slaughtered it in the place he broke into, he is exempt, for if there is no stealing, there is no slaughtering and no selling.
67.6: If he had a kid which he had stolen and had slaughtered it at the place he broke into, he is liable, for he was already guilty of stealing before he came to the transgression of breaking in;
67.9: And if he had let us hear [the case of] breaking in [I would say that he is exempt from payment] because his breaking in is his warning, but [with regard to] Shabbat, [in] which [case] a warning is required, I might say that [it is] not [so] Therefore] it is necessary [to state both cases].
67.8: And it was necessary [to state both cases]. For if he had let us hear [the case of] Shabbat [I would have said that he is free from payment] because its prohibition is forever, but [in the case of] breaking in, which is only a prohibition for the moment, I might say, [that it is] not [so].
67.39: [It is written]: “If no harm comes, he shall be surely fined” (Exodus 21:22).
67.38: Resh Lakish raised an objection against R. Yohanan:
67.11: If one had a cow that he had stolen and he slaughtered it on Shabbat, he is liable for he was already guilty of stealing before he came to the prohibition of Shabbat;
67.13: Aha the son of Raba said to R. Ashi:
67.12: If he had a cow that he borrowed and he slaughtered it on Shabbat, he is exempt.
67.14: Does R. Papa come just to teach us the rule about the cow?
67.17: Lest you think [that] because R. Papa said
67.16: R. Papa comes to teach us the rule of a borrowed [cow].
67.18: that he becomes responsible for its food from the time of possession by “drawing it [to him],” here also he becomes responsible for any unpreventable accident from the time of borrowing, so he lets us hear [that it is not so].
67.31: He who has committed inadvertently an act which, if he had committed it intentionally, would have been punishable with death or with lashes, and [which is also punishable] with something else, R. Yohanan says
67.30: for when R. Dimi came [from Eretz Yisrael] he said:
67.37: for since he is exempt if they warned him, so he is exempt also when they did not warn him.
67.36: Resh Lakish says [that] he is exempt,
67.35: he is liable, for they did not warn him.
67.32: he is liable, and Resh Lakish says

68.25: “He that strikes a beast shall pay for it: life for life” and adjacent to it [comes the following verse] “And if a man wounds his neighbor, as he has done so shall it be done to him?” (Leviticus 24:18-19).
68.20: It comes from “one who strikes” and “one who strikes.
68.23: If we say, “And he that strikes a beast shall pay for it, and he that strikes a man shall be put to death,” (Leviticus 24:21) this is written about death.
68.28: But this verse refers to one who injures his fellow, and one who injures his fellow has to pay damages?
68.29: If it does not refer to a “striking” in which there is the value of a perutah, teach it in reference to a “striking” in which there is not the value of a perutah.
68.0: Does this not refer to the law concerning “harm”?
68.3: [It is written] “And if no harm follows, he shall be surely fined.” Does this not refer to the law concerning “harm”?
68.2: Some say: R. Yohanan raised an objection against Resh Lakish:
68.7: Has not the house of Hezekiah taught:
68.6: Is there anyone who holds that he who committed unintentionally an act which, if he had committed it intentionally would have been punishable with death [and which is also punishable with the payment of money] is obligated [to pay money]?
68.9: Rather when Ravin came [from Eretz Yisrael], he said:
68.8: [It is written] “He that kills a man . . . he that kills a beast:” Just as in [the case of] the killing of a beast you have made no distinction between [it being done] inadvertently and willfully, intentionally and unintentionally, by way of going down or by way of going up, so as to free exempt him [from the payment], but [to in any case] make him liable to pay, so also in [the case of] the killing of a person you shall make no distinction between [it being done] inadvertently and willfully, intentionally and unintentionally, by way of going down or by way of going up, so as to make him liable to pay money, but to free him from paying money?
68.11: they only disagree when the act committed inadvertently would, if committed willfully, have been punishable with lashes and something else.
68.10: Those who committed inadvertently an act which, if committed willfully, would have been punishable with death [and which is also punishable with the payment of money] — all agree that he is free [from the payment of money],
68.13: he is liable [to pay, because] only with regard to those who commit an act punishable with death, those punishable by death have all been compared together, but those liable for lashes have not been compared together.
68.15: he is free [from making the money payment, because] the Torah has expressly included those who commit an act punishable with lashes to be as those who commit an act punishable with death.
68.18: It comes from “that wicked man” (Numbers 35:31) and “that wicked man” (Deuteronomy 25:2),

69.20: Forbidden relations and relations forbidden in the second degree, they have no claim to fine [for rape] or for seduction [payment].
69.21: A woman who refuses [her husband] has no claim to fine [for rape] or for seduction [payment].
69.22: An aylonit has no claim to fine [for rape] or for seduction [payment]. And a woman who has gone out on account of an evil name, has no claim to fine [for rape] or for seduction [payment].
69.23: What are “forbidden relations” and what are “relations forbidden in the second degree”?
69.1: It necessarily [speaks of a case] where, while he struck him, he tore his silk garment.
69.0: Anyhow, he is not liable to pay damages?
69.3: And according to the Tanna of the House of Hezekiah, who says:
69.5: This cannot be, for it is written: “And he that kills a beast shall pay for it, and he that kills a man shall be put to death.”
69.4: [It is written] “He that kills a man . . . He that kills a beast” [etc.,] how does he know that it refers to a week-day and there is no distinction to be made? Perhaps it refers to Shabbat, [in which case] there is a distinction to be made with regard to the beast itself?
69.7: If they did not warn him, why should one who killed a man be put to death?
69.9: Therefore it can only refer to a week-day.
69.8: Rather it is clear that they warned him, and if [it happened] on Shabbat would he, if he killed a beast, pay for it?
69.13: If according to R. Meir, [the law regarding] his daughter is difficult, if according to R. Nehuniah ben Hakaneh, [the law regarding] his sister is difficult; [and] if according to R. Isaac [the law regarding] a mamzeret is difficult?
69.12: who says [that] the Torah has innovated and innovation in the matter of fines and [therefore] he pays although he is killed, according to whom does he place our Mishnah?
69.15: Therefore you must say that he holds like R. Johanan.
69.14: It would be alright if he would hold like R. Yohanan, [for] he could [then] resolve it like R. Yohanan.   But if he holds like Resh Lakish how can he resolve it?
69.17: According to Resh Lakish who says [that]
69.18: he is free [from paying the fine, because] the Torah has expressly included those who commit an act punishable by lashes to be as those who commit an act punishable by death, who is the Tanna who differs from R. Nehuniah b. Hakaneh? It is either R. Meir or R. Isaac.

2.25: there he was forced by an enactment which the Rabbis enacted, but here, he is not?
2.26: And if you say:  If he became ill he provides her with food, [then the question would still be] if she became ill, what is [the law]?
2.20: Therefore, if he became ill or she became ill, or she began to menstruate, he does not give her food.
2.21: There are those who put this as a question:
2.22: If he became ill, what is [the law]?
2.23: There the reason [he need not support her,] is because he is forced, and here too, he is also forced?
2.28: I am here? Or, perhaps, she can say to him, “His field has been flooded”?
2.29: And if you will say [that] she can say to him, “His field has been flooded” [then the question is,] if she began to menstruate, what is the law?
2.1: twice in the week the courts sit in the towns,
2.0: A virgin is married on the fourth day [of the week] and a widow on the fifth day, for
2.3: GEMARA. R. Joseph said: Rav Judah said [that] Shmuel said:
2.2: on the second day [of the week] and on the fifth day, so that if he [the husband] had a claim as to the virginity [of the bride] he could go early [on the morning of the fifth day of the week] to the court.
2.5: Because we have learned: If the time [determined for the marriage] arrived and they were not married, they eat of his [food] and they eat of terumah.”
2.4: Why did they [the rabbis] say: A virgin is married on the fourth day?
2.7: “A virgin is married on the fourth day.”
2.6: You might have thought that if the time arrived on the first day of the week he would have to supply her with food, therefore have we learned,
2.11: Which was taught and which was not taught?
2.10: He [Shmuel] attaches a Mishnah which was taught, to a Mishnah which was not taught!
2.12: This was taught and this was taught!
2.15: Rather if it was said, this is what was said: Rav Judah said [that] Shmuel said:
2.14: he attaches a Mishnah, the reason of which was explained, to a Mishnah, the reason of which was not explained.
2.17: Let her be married on the first day of the week, and if he has a virginity claim he could go early [on the morning of the second day of the week] to the court! The Sages watched over the interests of the daughters of Israel so that [the bridegroom] should prepare for the feast three days,
2.16: Why did they say, “A virgin is married on the fourth day of the week”? Because if he had a virginity claim he could go early the [next morning] to the court.
2.19: And now that we have learned that the sages “watched over the interests” that which we have learned: If the time arrived and they were not married, they eat of his [food] and they eat of terumah, if the time arrived on the first day of the week, since he cannot marry her, he does not give her food.
2.18: on the first day in the week, the second day in the week, and the third day in the week, and on the fourth day he marries her.
2.30: During her regular time there is no question that she cannot say to him,

6.24: Although they said [that] there is no mourning on a festival, he keeps [mourning] in private.
6.25: Joseph the son of Rava expounded in the name of Rava:
6.26: They taught this only if he had not yet had intercourse with her but if he had [already] intercourse, his wife may sleep with him.
6.27: But here we are dealing with a case where he had intercourse, and it still it teaches [that]
6.21: He sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.
6.28: he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women?
6.29: When did he say [this]? With regard to his wife becoming a menstruant.
6.1: And [during] all these days he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.
6.0: and he has the mandated act of intercourse and then separates from her. And [then] he observes the seven days of the [wedding] feast and after that he keeps the seven days of mourning.
6.3: [But this is] only [if] the father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride [died], because there is [then] no one who should prepare for them [for the wedding], but not [in case of] the reverse.
6.2: And they do not withhold jewellery from the bride all the thirty days.
6.5: They taught [this] only when water had [already] been put on the meat,
6.4: Rafram b. Papa said [that] R. Hisda said:
6.6: but if water had not [yet] been put on the meat, it is to be sold.
6.8: And in a city, although water had been put on the meat, it is sold.
6.11: But where [then] will you find [the rule] of R. Hisda?
6.10: And in a village, although water had not been put on the meat, it is not sold.
6.13: For instance, [in] Mata Mehasia, which is neither a city nor a village.
6.15: If his bread was baked and his meat prepared and his wine mixed and water had been put on the meat and the father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride died, they bring the dead [person] into a room and the bridegroom and the bride into the bridal chamber, and he has the mandated act of intercourse and [then] separates [himself from her]. And [then] he keeps the seven days of the [wedding-] feast and after that he keeps the seven days of mourning.
6.14: It has been taught according to R. Hisda:
6.17: And so [also] if his wife became a menstruant he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.
6.16: And all these days he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.
6.19: In any case he should not have relations with her on Friday night or Saturday night.
6.18: And they do not withhold jewelry from the bride all the thirty days.

99.24: in respect of dowry the assessment is determined by [the disposition of] the father.
99.25: [Such] a case occurred at Nehardea and the Nehardean judges judged [in favor of the daughters]. At Pumbedita also R. Hana b. Bizna collected [sustenance for daughters from movable property].
99.27: Go and return that property [to the heirs] otherwise I will order the seizure of your mansions.
99.21: Does this not refer to sustenance, and he holds like R. Yitzchak b. Yosef?
99.22: No; that case was in connection with dowry,
99.23: and Shmuel [acted] in accordance with his own view, for Shmuel said that
99.28: Ammi and R. Assi intended to sustain daughters out of movable property.
99.29: Ya’akov b. Idi said to them:
99.1: Just as sons receive their inheritance only from landed property, so one’s daughters are sustained only from landed property.
99.0: Joseph sat before R. Hamnuna while R. Hamnuna was sitting and saying:
99.3: Is it only from a man who leaves land that sons inherit while from him who leaves no land his sons do not inherit?
99.5: Maybe the master was referring to the ketubah [inherited by] male children?
99.7: The Master who is a great man understood precisely what I meant.
99.9: Rav provided sustenance [to daughters] from wheat taken from the “aliyah.”
99.38: I meant to say [dates] that are suitable for [spreading on] the reed-mat.

[Blessed are You, LORD, our God, sovereign of the universe,] who creates man in your image, fashioning perpetuated life. Blessed are You, LORD, creator of man. May the barren one exult and be glad as her children are joyfully gathered to her (in haste). Blessed are You, LORD, who gladden Zion with her Children. Grant perfect joy to these loving companions, as you did your creations in the Garden of Eden. Blessed are You, LORD, who grants the joy of groom and bride. Blessed are You, LORD, our God, sovereign of the universe, who created joy and gladness, groom and bride, mirth, song, delight and rejoicing, love and harmony and peace and companionship. Soon, LORD our God, may there ever be heard in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem voices of joy and gladness, voices of groom and bride, the jubilant voices of those joined in marriage under the bridal canopy, the voices of young people feasting and singing. Blessed are You, LORD, who causes the groom to rejoice with his bride.

41.25: but [how can we learn that] if the judges know the signatures of the witnesses, there is no need to testify before them? Perhaps I could say to you
41.26: that this is [generally] necessary, but it is different here, because the telling has been fulfilled before one.
41.27: And [how can we learn that] if the judges do not know the signatures of the witnesses, it is necessary to give evidence before every one?  Perhaps I could say to you
41.20: if the judges know the signatures of the witnesses, here is no need to testify before them;
41.22: if the judges do not know the signatures of the witnesses, it is necessary to testify before every one
41.23: Ashi raised a difficulty on this:
41.28: that this is not necessary, but it is different here, because the telling would not have been fulfilled at all.
41.29: Abba sat and said this tradition, that a witness may be a judge.
41.40: If the protest was on the grounds of robbery,
41.0: Rabbanai, the brother of R. Hiyya b. Abba, came to buy sesame and he said:
41.2: Witness and judge are joined together.
41.6: Because the father of your mother praised it, you also praise it!
41.9: Three that sat together to uphold a document, and two of them know the signatures of the witnesses and one does not know, before they sign, they may testify before him, and he  then signs  with them; after they have signed, they may not testify before him and he may not sign.
41.8: Safra said that R. Abba said that R. Isaac b. Shmuel b. Martha said that R. Huna said, and some say that R. Huna said that Rav said:
41.39: What was the nature of the protest?
41.38: If three sit to uphold a document and an objection was raised against one of them: If before they have signed [the attestation], they may give evidence regarding him, and he may [then] sign; after they have signed, they may not give evidence regarding him and he may not sign.
41.11: Did not R. Papi say in the name of Rava:
41.10: But do we write the attestation [to such a document]?
41.13: And here also it looks like a lie!
41.12: The judge’s attestation which is written before the witnesses give evidence as to their signatures is invalid, because it looks like a lie?
41.15: Before they have written the attestation they may testify before him and he then signs with them; after they have written the attestation, they may not testify before him and he may not sign.
41.18: a witness may be  a judge;
41.31: If three saw it and they are the court, two shall stand up and seat two of their colleagues beside the one, and they shall testify before them, and [then] they say: Sanctified is the new moon, sanctified; for one person is not believed by himself.
41.37: Abba said [that] R. Huna said [that] Rav said:
41.36: Leave alone the testimony as to the new moon, [for it is] biblical, and the upholding of documents is rabbinic.
41.35: That was also difficult to me, and I asked R. Yitzchak b. Shmuel b. Martha. and R. Yitzchak [asked] R. Huna, and R. Huna [asked] Hiyya b. Rav, and Hiyya b. Rav [asked] Rav, and he said to them:
41.33: Let them sit in their places and sanctify [the new moon]!
41.32: Now, if you should think that a witness may be a judge, why go through all this?

5.24: “And on the second day [of the week] he should not marry; but if on account of duress it is permitted.”
