5.27: And further, there [it states], “they made a custom” but here, “it is allowed”!
5.21: A decree is likely to be annulled, and [therefore] we do not abolish an enactment of the rabbis on account of a decree.
5.22: If so, on the third day he [the governor] would also come and have intercourse [with the bride]?
5.23: Out of doubt he does not move himself.
5.29: They say: “A general has come to town.”
5.0: What does it mean “they watched diligently over”?
5.3: But let her be married on the first day of the week and if he has a virginity claim he could go early [on the morning of the second day of the week] to the court?
5.2: Why did they say that a virgin is married on the fourth day? So that if he has a virginity claim he could go early the [next morning] to the court.
5.5: the first day of the week, and the second day of the week, and the third day of the week, and on the fourth day he marries her.
5.4: The Sages watched diligently over the interests of the daughters of Israel so that [the man] should prepare for the feast three days,
5.7: And on the second day [of the week] he shall not marry; and if on account of duress it is allowed.
5.6: And from [the time of] danger the people had a custom to marry on the third day and the sages did not stop them.
5.8: And on the second day [of the week] he shall not marry; and if on account of duress it is allowed.
5.11: If I say that they said,  then why does it just say that “they made it a custom”?
5.10: If I say that they said,
5.14: [That] they said: A virgin that gets married on the fourth day [of the week] shall first have sexual intercourse with the governor.
5.17: Because there are chaste women who would rather surrender themselves to death and [thus] come to danger.
5.19: There are loose women and there are also priestesses.
5.18: But teach them that [in a case of] duress [it] is allowed?
5.31: If he comes and passes by, let it be delayed.
5.37: If his bread was baked and his meat slaughtered and his wine mixed and the father of the bridegroom or the mother of the bride died, they bring the dead [person] into a room and the bridegroom and the bride into the huppah
5.36: And if you want I can say:
5.35: And if you want I can say:
5.34: His vanguard arrived on the third day.
5.33: Let him, [then], marry on the third day [of the week]!
5.32: It is not necessary [to state this but] that he came and stayed.

9.24: And if you will say [that] he does damage by [making] the wound, [then the question is,] with regard to one who does damage, does the halakhah follow R. Judah?
9.20: There are those who state the question this way:
9.21: And if you will say that the blood is the result of a wound [then the question is], does he need the blood and it is forbidden, or is he concerned with his own pleasure, and it is allowed?
9.22: And if you will say [that] he is concerned with his own pleasure and the blood comes out of itself, [then the question is] does the halakhah follow R. Judah or does the halakhah follow R. Shimon?
9.23: And if you will say [that] the halakhah follows R. Judah, [then the question is,] does he do damage by [making] the wound, or does he improve by [making] the wound?
9.1: And this is the same thing that R. Elazar said:
9.0: he should plug his finger into his ears
9.2: Why do the fingers of man resemble pegs?
9.5: This one is zeret, this one is kemitzah, this one is amah, this one is etzba and this one is gudal.
9.4: Shall I say because they are divided? [Surely] each one has been made for its own purpose! For the Master said:
9.7: That if one hears an unworthy thing he shall plug his fingers into his ears.
9.6: Rather, [the question is] why [are the fingers] curved like pegs?
9.9: Why is the whole ear hard and the ear-lap soft
9.8: A tanna of the school of R. Ishmael taught:
9.10: [So] that if a person hears an unworthy thing he shall bend the ear-lap into it.
9.12: A man shall not let his ears hear idle things, because they are burned first of [all] the organs.
9.15: And if you will say [that] the blood is stored up [in the womb, then the question is:] does he need the blood, and it is allowed: or does he need the opening, and it is forbidden?
9.14: Is it allowed to have sex for the first time on Shabbat? Is the blood [in the womb] stored up, or is it the result of a wound?
9.17: allowed; or does the halakhah follow R. Judah who says:
9.16: And if you will say [that] he needs the blood and the opening comes of itself, [then the question is:] Does the halakhah follow R. Shimon who says: A thing which is not intended is
9.19: And if you will say [that] the halakhah is according to R. Judah [then the question is], do damage in regard to the opening, or does he improve in regard to the opening?
9.18: A thing which is not intended is forbidden?

77.29: And [in the case of] the rapist and the seducer, she herself or her father may oppose [the marriage].

77.1: One who is forced to have intercourse cannot be compared to one who acts
77.0: the woman would ultimately have suffered the same pain from her husband. But they said to him:

77.2: willingly? Rather R. Nahman in the name of Rabbah b. Avuha:

77.38: Rava did not give the same reply as Abaye, because, having paid the fine, this is not a case of a sinner gaining an advantage.
77.11: Rather R. Nahman in the name of Rabbah b. Avuha:

77.12: The smart women among them declare that
77.15: Abaye replied: My nurse told me:

77.16: Like hot water on a bald head.
77.19: like the prick of the blood-letting lancet.
77.31: But as regards a rapist, though it makes sense that she [may refuse him since] it is written. “And she will be to him,” (Deuteronomy 2:29) with her consent,
77.30: This goes well with regard to one who has been seduced–it is written, “If her father will refuse” (Exodus 22:16). I know this only about her father, from where do I know that she herself may refuse? Scripture says, “will refuse,” in any case.
77.37: If a seducer who has acted against the wish of her father alone may be rejected either by her or by her father how much more so the rapist who has acted both against the wish of her father and against the wish of her.

76.42: Now then, if he had thrown her upon silk he would be exempt?
76.43: And should you say that the law is so indeed, has it not been taught: R. Shimon b. Judah stated in the name of R. Shimon:
76.24: But according to your line of reasoning, that which is taught,
76.25: “If he had relations with her and then she was married, she keeps the fine”, is it written “Then he shall give to the father of the girl who was not a married woman”?
76.27: In that case, since the state of maturity removes a daughter from her father’s authority and marriage also removes a daughter from her father’s authority [the two may be compared to one another]: Just as [in the case of] maturity, if she attains maturity after he had intercourse with her, [the fine] belongs to the girl herself, so too [in the case of] marriage, if she married after he had intercourse with her, [the fine] belongs to the girl herself. But as to betrothal, does it completely remove a daughter from her father’s authority?
76.21: What if he had intercourse and then she became betrothed?
76.23: Is it written, “Then he shall give to the father of the girl who was not a betrothed woman”?
76.44: A rapist does not pay compensation for the pain [he has inflicted] because
76.29: [In the case of] a betrothed girl her father and her husband jointly may invalidate her vows.
76.40: For the pain [he has inflicted] when he thrust her upon the ground.
76.1: Did not R. Bibi say in front of R. Nahman:
76.3: A minor, a pregnant woman and nursing mother.
76.2: Three [categories of] women may use a contraceptive sponge:
76.5: And what is [the age of such] a minor? From the age of eleven years and one day to the age of twelve years and one day.
76.4: The minor, lest she become pregnant and die. A pregnant woman, lest the intercourse cause her fetus to become a sandal. A nursing mother, lest she have to wean her child [prematurely] and this would result in his death.
76.6: One who is under, or over this age should have relations in the normal manner, the words of R. Meir.
76.9: And should you say that this is a case where she conceived when she was a na’arah and gave birth to a child when she was still a na’arah, can she give birth to a child within six months [after conception]?
76.8: All of them should have relations in the normal manner, and God will have mercy on them from Heaven, as it says, “The Lord preserves the simple” (Psalms 116:6).
76.11: The period between the age of na’aruth and that of bagrut (maturity) is only six months?
76.13: that there were no less but more [than six months] didn’t he say “only”!
76.12: And should you suggest [that he meant to say]
76.15: Is the state of maturity attainable in the grave and her father consequently forfeits [his right], or is perhaps
76.14: Rather this is what he asked:
76.17: Mar son of R. Ashi raised the question in the following manner:
76.16: the state of maturity not attainable in the grave and the father, therefore, does not forfeit [his right]?
76.18: Does death effect maturity or not?
76.31: The seducer pays compensation for embarrassment and blemish and the fine; The rapist pays an additional [form of compensation] in that he pays for the pain.
76.30: Mishnah: 1. The seducer pays three forms [of compensation] and the rapist four.
76.37: 4 If she was found to have committed a licentious act or was unfit to marry an Israelite he may not continue to live with her, for it is said, “And she shall be for him a wife”(Deut. 22:29)—a wife that is fit for him.
76.36: 3 What is meant by “he must drink out of his pot”? Even if she is lame, even if she is blind and even if she is afflicted with boils [he may not dismiss her].
76.35: The rapist must “drink out of his pot” but the seducer may dismiss [the girl] if he wishes.
76.34: The rapist pays immediately but the seducer [pays only] if he dismisses her.

76.32: 2 What [is the difference] between [the penalties of] a seducer and those of a rapist?

75.24: We are dealing here with the case of a virgin who was once betrothed and is now divorced, and they differ in the same dispute as R. Akiva of the Mishnah and R. Akiva of the baraita.
75.26: If he had intercourse with her and she died, he is exempt [from the fine], as it says, “Then he shall give to the girl’s father” (Deuteronomy 22:29) but not to the father of a deceased girl.
75.27: The ruling which was so obvious to Abaye was part of a question asked by Rava.
75.20: To whom is the fine given? To her father. Others say:
75.29: Is the age of maturity legally attainable in the grave or not?
75.1: that “virgin” should be used for the gezerah shavah and “who was not betrothed” [should be used to] exclude a girl that was betrothed and divorced?
75.3: On the contrary; “virgin” should be used for the gezerah shavah, for she is still called “one who has not been betrothed.”
75.2: stands to reason that “who has not been betrothed” should be used for the gezerah shavah,  since such a girl is still a na’arah that is a virgin.
75.5: As to R. Yose the Galilean, where does he derive the reasoning [that the payment for rape is the same as that for seduction]?
75.4: It is reasonable, for the body of the one had undergone a change while that of the other had not.
75.7: “He shall pay money according to the bride-price of virgins” (Exodus 22:16)— that this [payment] shall be the same sum as the bride-price of the virgins and the bride-price of virgins shall be the same as this.
75.6: He derives it from the following where it was taught:
75.9: There were two tannaim, both reciting the statements of R. Akiva.
75.8: One statement of R. Akiva contradicts the other statement of R. Akiva?
75.10: It goes well for R. Akiva in our Mishnah since the gezerah shavah does not altogether remove the verse from its simple meaning. But according to R. Akiva in the baraita, the gezerah shavah removes the verse completely from its simple meaning!
75.13: But a betrothed girl is obligated for the death penalty!
75.12: Read the text [as if it says]: “Who is not betrothed”.
75.15: since it is an innovation that the Torah innovated by establishing a fine, even though he is executed, he must still pay.
75.17: who said that the innovation that the Torah innovated with regard to a fine is that even though he is executed he still pays a fine, what can he say?
75.18: He holds like R. Akiva in our Mishnah.
75.30: Is the age of maturity attainable in the grave and [the fine, therefore,] belongs to her son, or is perhaps the age of maturity not attainable in the grave and [the fine, therefore,] belongs to her father?

74.24: The verse said, “Who has not been betrothed”—if she has been betrothed she does not receive the fine.
74.26: “Who has not been betrothed”—[in such a case the fine goes] to her father. If she has been betrothed, it goes to her.
74.27: If so, then “A na’arah” but not a girl who reached majority age, here too the fine should go to her.
74.20: A girl who was betrothed and then divorced—Rabbi Yose the Galilean says:
74.21: she does not receive a fine. Rabbi Akiva says:
74.22: she receives the fine and the fine belongs to her.
74.23: GEMARA. What is the reason of R. Yose the Galilean?
74.28: [Likewise the expression] “Virgin” but not one who is no longer a virgin, here too the fine should go to her!
74.29: Rather the exclusion is complete, and here too it should be complete!
74.40: And R. Akiva—what did you see [to use] “Who has not been betrothed” for a gezerah shavah and “virgin” to exclude one who was no longer a virgin?
74.1: but that where murder was committed in the course of a downward movement, which [is an offence that] may be atoned for if committed unwittingly, a monetary fine may be received from him and thereby he may be exempted [from the death penalty]. Hence we were taught [that in no circumstances may he pay a ransom to avoid a death penalty].
74.0: this applied only where murder had been committed in the course of an upward movement, because no atonement is allowed when such an act was committed unwittingly
74.3: Does not this  follow from what a Tanna of the House of Hezekiah [taught]! For a tanna of the house of Hezekiah taught:
74.4: It is written] “He that kills a man . . . he that kills a beast:” Just as in [the case of] the killing of a beast you have made no distinction between [it being done] inadvertently and willfully, intentionally and unintentionally, by way of going down or by way of going up, so as to free exempt him [from the payment], but [to in any case] make him liable to pay, so also in [the case of] the killing of a person you shall make no distinction between [it being done] inadvertently and willfully, intentionally and unintentionally, by way of going down or by way of going up, so as to make him liable to pay money, but to free him from paying money?
74.8: this is so only where a man blinded another man’s eye and thereby killed him, but that where he blinded his eye and killed him by another act a monetary fine must be exacted from him.
74.39: and as there [the coins must be] shekels so here also they must be shekels.
74.38: Here it is said, “Who has not been betrothed” and elsewhere it is said, “Who has not been betrothed” (Exodus 22:15). Just as here [the fine is that of] fifty [silver coins] so is it fifty [silver coins] there also;
74.11: for a Tanna of the House of Hezekiah [taught:]
74.10: This is also deduced from another statement of the Tanna of the House of Hezekiah;
74.12: “Eye for eye” but not an eye and a life for an eye?
74.17: But according to Rabbah, who said that
74.16: since the law of a monetary fine is an innovation innovated by the Torah, one must pay the fine even though he is also executed. Therefore it teaches us [that he is only executed].
74.19: He holds like the first Tanna who argued R. Hanania b. Akavia.
74.18: the innovation that the Torah innovated with regard to a fine is that even though he is executed he still pays a fine, how does he use the verse, “None proscribed…”
74.31: The verse “not betrothed” is required for that which is taught:
74.37: If so what does Scripture mean when it says “Who has not been betrothed”? It is free for the purpose of a comparison with it and an inference from it by means of a gezerah shavah.
74.36: that since her father is entitled to have the money of her betrothal and he is also entitled to have the money of her fine, just as the money of her betrothal belongs to her father even after she had been betrothed and divorced, so also the money of her fine should belong to her father even after she had been betrothed and divorced.
74.34: She receives the fine and her fine [is given] to her father.
74.32: “Who has not been betrothed”—this excludes a girl that was betrothed and then divorced who has no claim to a fine, the word of R. Yose the Galilean.

73.24: It might have been true even before his sentence had been completed? Scripture says,
73.26: According to R. Hanania b. Akabia who ruled that
73.27: the value of such a person may be vowed because its price is fixed, what deduction does he make from the text of “None proscribed”?
73.20: Scripture says, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself” (Leviticus 19:18)—choose for him a good death.
73.21: “None proscribed, that may be proscribed of men, shall be ransomed” (Leviticus 27:29)? —Why do I need this verse?
73.22: It is required for that which is taught:
73.23: From where do we know that if a person was being led to his execution, and someone said, “I vow to give his value [to the Temple]” he has said nothing? As it is said, “None proscribed, that may be proscribed of man, shall be ransomed.”
73.28: He requires it for that which was taught: R. Ishmael the son of R. Yohanan b. Beroka said:
73.29: Since we find that those who incur the penalty of death at the hand of heaven may pay a monetary fine and thereby obtain atonement, as it is said, “If a ransom be placed on him” (Exodus 21:3) it might [have been assumed that] the same law applied also [to those who are sentenced to death] at the hands of men. Therefore, Scripture says. “None proscribed of men can be ransomed.”
73.0: and one refers to the penalties of death and lashes.
73.3: And if it had taught us only that he cannot be executed and receive lashes, it would be because we do not do two things against his body, but execution and a fine, where one is against his body and one against his property, I might have said we could do this, therefore both are necessary.
73.2: For if we had been told only that one cannot be executed and pay a fine, this would be because we don’t punish a person with his body and with his money, but when it comes to death and lashes, both of which are with his body, I might have said that this is one long death, and we should perform it.
73.5: The Torah has stated, “Do not take money and exempt him from death.”
73.4: “And you shall take no ransom for one who has killed” (Numbers 35:31)?
73.6: “And do not take a ransom to flee to the city of refuge” (Numbers 35:32). This means do not take money from him and exempt him from exile.
73.11: For if we had been told of intentional murder only it might have been assumed [that the restriction applied to this case only], because the transgression for which death is inflicted is grave, but not to the one of unintentional killing where the transgression is not so grave.
73.10: One deals with unwitting [killing], and the other with intentional [murder]. And [both texts] were required.
73.13: “And no atonement can be made for the land for the blood that is shed on it, but by the blood of him that shed it” (Numbers 35:33)—Why do I need this verse?
73.12: And if we had been told of unintentional killing only it might have been assumed [that the restriction applied to this case only] because no loss of life is involved, but not to intentional murder where a loss of life is involved. Therefore, both were required.
73.15: From where do we know that if the heifer’s neck was broken and then the murderer was found, how do we know that we do not let him go? As it is said, “And no atonement can be made for the land for the blood that is shed therein, but by the blood of him that shed it.” “So you shall expunge the clean blood in your midst” (Deuteronomy 21:9)
73.14: It was required for the following:
73.17: From where do we know that execution by the sword must be at the neck? Scripture says, “So you shall expunge the clean blood in your midst”– all who shed blood are compared to the heifer with the broken neck: Just as its head is cut at the neck so is those who shed blood [cut] at the neck.
73.16: —Why do I need this verse? It is required for that which is taught:
73.19: Nahman answered in the name of Rabbah b. Avuha:
73.18: If so, just as there [its head is cut] with an axe and at the back of the neck so here too?
73.31: But is this not derived directly from “You shall take no ransom” which implies:
73.30: I know this only concerning severe death penalties since [they are imposed for offences] which cannot be atoned for if committed unwittingly; how do I know the same is true for lighter death penalties seeing that [they are for offences] that may be atoned for if committed unwittingly? Scripture says, “None proscribed.
73.32: You shall take no money from him to exempt him [from death]? Why do I need the verse, “None devoted”? —

72.24: And were you to suggest that R. Yose did not refer to the case of unexpected occurrence, there is the case of a woman who was raped or seduced which may happen unexpectedly and yet it was taught:
72.25: A woman who has been raped or seduced must wait three months, the words of R. Judah, but R. Yose permits immediate betrothal and marriage!
72.20: This makes sense in the case of a convert, since her intention is to convert, she guards herself.
72.21: It also makes sense in the case of a captive [who is also careful] since she does not know where they will take her
72.22: It also makes sense in the case of a slave woman [who might also be careful] when she hears from her master.
72.23: What, however, can be said in the case of one who is freed on account of the loss of a tooth or an eye?
72.28: a woman who fornicates turns over in order to prevent conception.
72.40: One refers to the penalties of death and money
